speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: We'll hear argument in Deck against the State of Missouri. Ms. Percival.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Did the -- did counsel suggest less intrusive restraints?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: What was the basic justification in the first place for shackling?  I mean, were there insufficient bailiffs or -- or why did they do it in -- even in -- during the trial itself?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Is there any indication that there were or were not present court security officers?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Who -- who should -- whose responsibility should it be to get something like that into the record?  I mean, I read it.  I don't -- I have no idea whether there was a good reason for the shackling or not.

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: What's the authority for the burden of proof question?  What -- what -- which of our cases do you rely on for that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: So the principle is there's a right not to be shackled, and when the State says that that right has to be compromised, then the State has to have the burden of proof?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: And I looked -- and I find that rule in Chapman?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Those -- those are all, are they not, cases involving the -- the guilt phase of -- of a trial? Right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, this is a little different. He -- I mean, when you shackle somebody who hasn't yet been convicted, you -- you send a message to the jury that, you know, this -- this person belongs in irons. But the jury had already found this person guilty.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: He was -- he was convicted.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Should that make no difference?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Guilty.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Can -- can I ask you?  You say counsel proposed some alternatives to -- to the visible shackling.  Did counsel object that there shouldn't have been any shackling at all?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Okay.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: But he did take the position that there was no need for shackles at all.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Back on your earlier part of your answer to Justice Scalia, that it's inherently prejudicial in the sentencing stage, if one of us were to agree or the whole Court, the majority, were to agree with your position and write the opinion out, what would we cite for that, other -- other than our -- our own assumptions as to how the system worked, judicial notice?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: With -- with character, we know -- we know he's a murderer.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Are you sure that it's as -- as prejudicial in the -- in the penalty phase as it is in the guilt phase?  I mean, in the guilt phase, it does make the person look like a criminal.  In the penalty phase, I -- I'm really not sure if I -- if I were a prosecutor whether I would prefer to have the defendant shackled or not.  The issue before the jury is whether to leave this person in his -- in his current incarcerated state for life or to execute him.  And I -- I might think that showing, you know, what -- what kind of an existence it is to be -- to be a life prisoner walking around with the legirons and chains -- I'm not sure that that is going to cut in favor of the jury's giving the death penalty or -- or to the contrary, make the juror think, boy, what a wretched life this is and -- and that ought to be enough.

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: What are the factors in Missouri that the State would be trying to prove to urge the imposition of death versus life imprisonment?  What are the things in Missouri that are deemed relevant?

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: Is future dangerousness an issue in Missouri?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Does your whole case turn on how shackling affects the argument that you're -- that the accused is making that he's not dangerous, et cetera, or is there some other different standard that we could use Page 10 to the effect, say, that it's just not consistent with the dignity in an American courtroom, something like that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Does your whole case turn on whether or not this is prejudicial to the fact-finding process on the specific issues or is there some more general standard?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: In the prison setting, does he wear such restraints?  Justice Scalia suggested the jury might say, wow, that's the way he has to go around the rest of his life with the -- all chained up.  But in -- do we know whether in the prison he would be routinely wearing these restraints?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: It's --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, I mean, I think the --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- it's still an oppressive reminder of -- of how this individual, if sentenced to life, is -- is subject to -- to the orders of prison authorities which on some occasions will subject him to this kind of restraint. I -- once again, if I were a prosecutor, I'd rather have him dressed up in a nice, new suit and his hair combed and smiling.  I would much prefer that to having him in shackles.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Are you aware of any cases in which prosecutors have objected to shackling?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: So Justice Scalia would have, I suppose, but he's unusual as a prosecutor I think. (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, I -- I think there is -- is something to the point that if I'm a juror and the defendant is sitting about as close to me as you are at Page 12 the counsel table and I see that he can't suddenly jump out at me, I have a certain -- certain security in making a deliberated judgment.  I -- I do think it may cut both ways.  And that's why I'm asking you is if there are some other considerations here.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Let me ask you this.  You, of course, would object to having to show prejudice in any individual case.  Then it seems to me, to follow, that that's prejudice -- that that means because prejudice is difficult to show.  And if prejudice is judicial -- difficult to show, why should we rule for you anyway?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Is --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: What do you make of the judge -- well, the jury, already having been polled, and every one of them said this would not affect our judgment?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Suppose the judge had said this defendant has just been convicted of killing two people. He convicted them -- as the jury knows, he was convicted of having killed them because he wanted to avoid being Page 15 sent back to prison.  The jury may sit there and think, well, if he killed two people to avoid being sent back to prison and we've just voted him guilty, maybe he's going to try to lunge out in the courtroom and get us.  And therefore, I want him shackled.  Now, suppose the judge had said that.  Would that be an adequate reason?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: I -- I think you have to give that answer to Justice -- to Justice Breyer, and that's why I'm asking.  I -- I think you just have to say that this is inherently inconsistent with the atmosphere we want to have in a courtroom.  It seems to me -- I -- I'm not quite sure I can find a lot of authority for that, but it seems to me that has to be your argument.

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: Well, Ms. Percival, would you still be here today with this argument if the defendant had simply had shackles around his ankles that would have prevented him, in -- in effect, from running or lunging at anyone, but that that had been concealed by appropriate covers around the table where he was sitting so that the Page 16 jury was unaware of that situation?

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: Would you still be here --

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: -- making this argument that it's inherently prejudicial even though the jury couldn't see it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: That wasn't obvious or visible particularly to the jury.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, but then you're giving away the Riggins argument, which is that this somehow affects the psyche of the defendant and he can't fully participate, et cetera, which I thought was your argument.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: So can every defendant have leg braces in every case?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Well, is -- you -- you have -- Justice Kennedy alluded to one of your earlier arguments, and that is the -- somehow the -- the shackling affects the capacity to participate.  I thought you meant by that if the -- the hands are shackled, he can't write notes to counsel.  Do you mean something else?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Well, I -- I would grant you if -- if they -- they are so tight that it's causing pain, you've got a separate problem, but short of that, does the Page 18 so-called capacity to participate suffer simply because he's -- he's in irons?  I mean, the only participation that he's going to do, I presume, is -- is sit there and -- and communicate with his lawyer.  It's going to affect his capacity to write a note to his lawyer.  What else is it going to do?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Do you know of any instance of that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But he does have to stand up when the judge comes in --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: -- and presumably when the jury files in.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: But your -- your problem with that, as I understand it, is simply that at that point with all these chains and so on, he's giving an impression Page 19 or the State is requiring him, in effect, to give an impression to the jury that may be a -- a false impression.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Okay.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: But back to participation.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: But that would be true if he were in the legirons.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: True, true.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I gather there was some evidence or perhaps it's conceded that he was put on a suicide watch before his first trial.  This was the second trial.  Right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: That he had been put on a suicide watch and that he had tried to injure himself by knocking his head against the cell wall?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: What if -- what if the judge had specifically stated I'm putting him in irons because the man is -- is violent enough towards himself or others that I'm worried about the safety of the jury.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: What if the judge had said that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Would that have been enough?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Yes, you may, Ms. Percival. Ms. Nield.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Well, isn't -- isn't the question whether he -- he was dangerous in the courtroom?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: There's no question he was dangerous when he committed the murders, but -- but I don't know that that means he's dangerous in a courtroom.

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: Well, is there some burden on the part of the prosecutor and the court to consider at least alternative restraints or measures to make sure that there's no misbehavior?

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: Well, apparently that was done.  Do you say that there was no motion made by defense counsel and that alternatives were not proposed?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Do you -- do you take the position that every defendant can be restrained if the restraints are not visible to the jury?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Legirons strapped to the leg of the -- of the table but not visible.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Why don't you limit it to double murderers anyway?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Okay.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, but I want to know what your position is. Traffic offenders?

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: Well, the circumstances that you were given was a traffic offender.

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: With -- with non-visible restraints. Is that perfectly okay?

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: It's kind of an extreme position, isn't it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Is --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But this -- this is given -- I mean, this is legirons.  It's not leg braces.  Belly chain.  You don't need to make a record to -- to know that those things are visible.  Is there any serious doubt that they were visible?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: What about his motion?  Is Mr. Leftwich -- is that defense counsel?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: All right, fine.  He says I would ask that or like to move to strike the entire jury panel for cause because of the fact that Mr. Deck is shackled in front of the jury and makes them think that he is going to -- that he is violent today and going to do Page 25 something in the courtroom.  And I read that, he's saying, of course, they can see it.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: That doesn't say he can see it -- they can see it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: All right.  So has anybody said -- he said, Judge, I would like you to get rid of this jury which happens to be looking at the shackles.  Okay. Now, at that point, you have to do -- then isn't it up to the prosecution to say, what do you mean looking at them? They can't see them.  They're hidden.

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: Well, are you taking the position here that this record does not disclose that the belly chains and the handcuffs and the other restraints were not visible?

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: That there's nothing in the Page 26 record to show that.

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: And you don't concede it.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Yes, but your position would be precisely the same if the record made it perfectly clear that the jury could see everything, I think.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Yes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: So this is an alternative argument that you're making.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But the State of Missouri is submitting to us the proposition that every defendant in every case can be shackled so long as it's not visible. And I -- I find that an extreme position because it's an indignity on the defendant and the defendant is entitled to dignity in a courtroom.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Could he be forced to wear prison clothes once he's convicted and it's the sentencing phase?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But there's no for example here because the court said, in answer to the lawyer's objection -- the -- the lawyer says, it prejudiced him -- prejudices him toward the jury and it makes him look dangerous.  The court's answer:  the objection you're making will be overruled.  He has been convicted and will remain in legirons and belly chain.  The only thing that was relevant, according to the trial judge was he has been convicted.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Why?  He went through the entire guilt phase with the more moderate restraints, just the leg brace, and there was no incident.  There was no disturbance in that trial.  He didn't try to lash out at anyone.  Why wasn't that the best example of what one could anticipate in the penalty phase?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Is the fact of conviction critical for your point of view because it doesn't really matter if there's prejudice or that because there's no -- no danger of prejudice?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Well, do you concede that even though he had been convicted, it would, nevertheless, be prejudicial in the eyes of the jury to see a man shackled when one of the issues they'll have to decide is whether his future dangerousness might -- might justify his Page 29 execution?  Do you think there is prejudice there, or do you share Justice Scalia's view that it would be a good thing for the defendant?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: And if it depends, why would it not be appropriate to have a rule that the trial judge should be required to explain the basis for his decision?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Yes, but would you not agree that it's always of relevance to a jury in deciding whether the -- the man should be executed, is how dangerous is this guy?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: But the fact --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Could they put him in a cage?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: He's -- he's been convicted. We know he's dangerous.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: It seems to me your argument is much like arguing on the merits of the -- at the original trial that his defense was alibi or something like that, therefore you don't have to worry about the Page 31 prejudice that arises from the restraints.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Yes, but the bottom line from the other point of view is that shackles are always prejudicial, and you try to have the scales evenly balanced when you're deciding whether the man should die or not.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Well, the -- the stated aggravating circumstances didn't, but the point of -- one point of the argument is that by shackling the man in -- in this complete and visible way, you are creating the impression that no one could fail to -- to perceive that this guy is so dangerous that they can't even depend upon courtroom security either to protect him from the -- Page 32 protect the jurors or courtroom personnel or to prevent escape.  That -- excuse me.  That may not be a verbal argument about dangerousness, but it seems to me that it is an unmistakably visible one.  What is your response to that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Do we know why the judge apparently changed his mind?  Because if I remember correctly, at the pretrial hearing, the court said that the defendant would be allowed to, A, wear his own clothes and, B, to have leg braces underneath for security.  And then sometime after that pretrial hearing, the judge apparently changed his mind.  Do we know what triggered that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: Well, how about the ones that were used on Mr. Deck during the trial?  Was that an alternative that was reasonable?

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: Well, in part it depends on Page 34 whose burden it is. Is it the burden of the State, if they're going to use shackles, to somehow establish that it's needed?

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: Or do you take the position that they're free to impose shackles in every case, even a traffic offense, if the prosecutor wishes to do it, without any justification? That's your position apparently.

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: Is that right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: Is that your position?

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: No?

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: That's not my question, and -- and it relates to what is the burden of the State in these situations to use the visible restraints?

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: And where in this record do I find that the State carried that burden --

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: -- and that there was a finding by the trial judge on it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: Could you point me to places in the record where it supports your position on the use of the visible restraint?

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: Had that not occurred before he was even tried?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: And what were the facts of the aiding escape? Was he trying to get away or was he helping somebody?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: I mean, what did he do? Draw a map or what? Page 36 (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Which really has very little probative value on this issue.  I mean, the fact that he tried to saw his way out of a cell hardly speaks to the risk of fleeing from the courtroom while the proceedings are going on.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: So we already know that -- that that effort was made before he was tried in the guilt phase.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: And whatever inference you might draw, it didn't prove out.  So it seems to me the -- the closest in time is the -- and -- and in fact is the episode he's just been through, the trial episode.  So why wouldn't that be -- the -- the judge would start with that in mind.  Well, I tried this man and he didn't give me any Page 37 problems, so I have no reason to anticipate problems now.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: If -- if there are some factors that favor putting him in shackles and I guess others might not, what's the argument that the judge shouldn't at least have to make a finding?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I mean, you know, I realize you want to save the conviction and the penalty, but if you look at the mine run of cases, it's pretty hard for me to see how the State could show special circumstances and they not get a finding from the judge that they're right.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: It's pretty hard to see an argument against it.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I know that hurts your case, but I -- I still need to think of some argument or reason why the judge shouldn't have to at least make a finding.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: With a -- with a blank record -- the -- the State is going to restrain someone and it may be necessary, it may be not, and if the State has the burden, then why shouldn't a reviewing court speculate on what might have been when the only thing that was -- appears of record is he's been convicted and will remain in legirons?  The only reason the court gave is that now things have changed.  He's no longer in the guilt phase where he enjoys the presumption of innocence.  He has been convicted and, therefore, we can keep him in chains. There's nothing situation-specific about it. The judge seems to be saying once a person is convicted, at least of murder, it's fair game.  It's -- it's permissible to keep him in legirons and shackles.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Ms. Nield, is -- is the State making a harmless error argument here?  I really couldn't tell from your brief whether you're doing it or not.  Are -- are -- is the State asserting that assuming it -- assuming it was wrong, assuming it was a violation, this jury would have -- would have come out the same way anyway?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Why is that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: What -- what specific aggravating circumstances did they jury find?  You say there are statutory aggravating circumstances in Missouri.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: And the jury found -- there are five.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: And the jury found all five.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Six.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: So -- so it's never ground for reversal? I'm -- I'm wondering, in line with Justice Scalia's question, is -- is -- would the calculus be, well, this is not a close case and some other cases are closer? I mean, is that what we do?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Your -- your -- I -- I think first position at least would be that it's never prejudicial. But assume we don't agree with that.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: How does harmless error work to -- to pursue Justice Scalia's line of questioning?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: I understand that.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: But answer his question. Give Page 43 him an example of where it -- it wouldn't be harmless error.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Assuming that it is a violation, what's an example of where it wouldn't be harmless error?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Or I suppose if future dangerousness was a specific aggravating factor under State law, as it is in Texas, for example --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- then -- then you would concede that if this was unlawful, the error clearly would Page 44 not be harmless.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: I thought the question here was, was he dangerous in the courtroom?  Was he going to lash out at a witness or try to --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: If he -- if he were kept under these restraints, legirons and the -- what do they call it -- belly chain, day in and day out in prison, would that constitute cruel or unusual punishment?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Thank you, Ms. Nield. Ms. Percival, you have about 4 and a half minutes left.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Could -- could you comment on whether or not there's harmful error here?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Are you asking us to say that in light of six aggravating factors on which he was convicted, the result likely would have been different?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: That was at this trial or at the first trial, that --

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: May I ask one quick question?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Does the record tell us how big he was?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Okay. The case is submitted.
